_prev_prog_3.Description: This program will be described in the Executive Summary

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The OSHA PSM and the EPA RMP plans work together to assure that potential on-site hazards and

off-site consequences are identified and controlled. All 14 elements of the OSHA PSM program, the

EPA requirement for developing an Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA), and the RMP submittal

are included within the facility's prevention program.



DESCRIPTION OF FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Boardman, Oregon cold storage facility stores various potato products such as French Fries of

various shapes and seasonings and formed potato products.  The covered process at the facility is a closed loop anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system.  There is one independent refrigeration system at the facility, with more than the Threshold Quantity (TQ) of anhydrous ammonia.



DESCRIPTION OF THE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The OSHA PSM component elements are organized as follows: 1) Employees participate in the

elements of this safety and release prevention program whenever possible; 2) Ammonia awareness

and PSM training is provided to all employees, operators and maintenance personnel receive

additional training; 3) Process Safety Information (PSI) is maintained on the covered processes; 4)

Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) of the covered processes were conducted and will be periodically

reviewed to ensure adequacy of controls; 5) The Mechanical Integrity program ensures the covered

processes will continue to operate as designed; 6) Operating and Maintenance procedures provide

operators and maintenance staff the information necessary to safely operate and maintain the

covered processes; 7) Contractors working on or near the system are selected through a rigorous

review of their safety performance and relevant experience, and are briefed on the hazards and

safety requirements of the job before being allowed to perform work at the facility; 8) Hot Work

Permits are required whenever welding, cutting, grinding or other a

ctivities are conducted on or near

the covered processes could generate sparks and possibly compromise the integrity of one or more

of the processes; 9) The Management of Change (MOC) program requires that the impact of

changes to the covered processes be evaluated and approved prior to work being conducted; 10)

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR) are conducted prior to restart of a covered process after

modifications, to ensure the impacts of the change are addressed; 11) Incident Investigations are

conducted for incidents involving ammonia releases and near misses that endanger employees or

the public; 12) Compliance Audits are conducted every three years to ensure that the prevention

program is meeting its objectives; 13) Emergency Planning and Response ensures that employees

and emergency personnel are prepared to react to an ammonia release, and that notifications are

made to key personnel and authorities at the local, state and federal levels depending on the extent

of the release; and 14) Trade Secrets do not hinder the dissemination of information regarding the

covered processes, to all employees.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no reportable releases of the covered process chemical, anhydrous ammonia, at

the Boardman, Oregon facility in the last five years.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Boardman, Oregon facility plans does not respond to releases of the covered process chemical,

anhydrous ammonia, and therefore has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP). The EAP

has been reviewed with the Boardman Fire Department and the Morrow County Local Emergency

Planning Committee (LEPC). The purpose of the plan is to establish policies and procedures for

protecting the health and safety of employees, contractors, and visitors, and to comply with all

applicable federal and state regulations. Training of employees and contractors includes providing a

copy of the plan upon initial employment at Lamb Weston, Inc. and reviewing it for

their specific

assignment, annual refresher training for current employees, and review for all whenever the plan is

changed. In addition, plant evacuation drills are conducted on a regular basis.  The plan is comprehensive enough to deal with all types of emergencies specific to the Boardman, Oregon facility and defines the following: Preferred means for reporting fires, Hazardous materials incidents, Medical, and any other emergencies; Emergency escape routes and assembly areas; Procedures to account for all employees including contractors and visitors; and Names of agencies and persons to contact.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Safety systems and preventative maintenance measures will be constantly evaluated and improved.

The facility will evaluate recommendations from Process Hazard Analyses and Compliance Audits in

a timely manner and implement, as soon as possible, those recommendations that will reduce the

possibility of a release and/or mitigate the consequence of an unintentional release.
